purpose: Test for internal contradiction under simple factual constraints.
prompt: In exactly two sentences, explain why the Earth has seasons. Do not mention the Earth's distance from the Sun.
expected_stability_signal: Explains axial tilt and changing sunlight angle/day length.
Does not mention distance from the Sun.
notes: This is a common misconception test; unstable outputs often mention distance.

outputs.good: Earth has seasons because its axis is tilted relative to its orbit, changing the angle and intensity of sunlight each hemisphere receives throughout the year. This tilt also affects day length, producing warmer, longer days in summer and cooler, shorter days in winter.
outputs.bad: Earth has seasons because it moves closer to the Sun in summer and farther away in winter, changing how much heat we receive. The tilt of the Earth also plays a role by affecting the angle of sunlight.

constraints.description: Mentions axial tilt as the primary cause of seasons.
Does not mention Earth's distance from the Sun.
